questions.text: A 40-year-old male was found shot dead in a parking lot. Forensic examination revealed that the cause of death was a shotgun injury. Considering the type of injury, what is the probable range of the shot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) < 1 metre

 

Explanation:

  • A close-shot injury (< 1 metre) has a circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, and singeing of hair.
  • The wound track and surrounding tissues appear cherry-red due to carbon monoxide absorption.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Quaternary blast injury

Explanation

The provided scenario and accompanying image of traumatic asphyxia, which is a characteristic of quaternary blast injury.

 

  • Types of Blast injuries

 

Type of injury

Caused by

Features

Primary blast injury

(Option A)

Blast waves
  • Commonly internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture
  • Lungs: Alveolar, capillary, and membrane hemorrhage leading to blast lung (most common causes of death among survivors)
  • GIT: Vomiting, melena, hematemesis, perforation.

Secondary blast injury

(Option B)

Shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion)
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Marshall triad: Includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations.
  • Thoracic injuries

(Option C)

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds
  • Blunt or penetrating trauma.
  • Bone fractures and coup-countercoup injury.

(Option D)

Environmental contaminants, chemicals, radiations (nuclear bomb), virus and bacteria

questions.text: A 40-year-old male diver is brought to the emergency department after an underwater explosion and complains of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and difficulty breathing. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the abdomen. Which organ is most commonly injured in this patient due to the underwater blast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Colon

 

Explanation:

In Underwater explosions, injuries to gas-filled organs are more frequent, with the Colon being the most commonly affected organ.

 

Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion that causes sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

 

Types of Blast Exposure:

  • Air Blast: Causes less severe injuries due to energy dissipation.
  • Immersion Blast: Force transmitted through water, leading to more severe injuries due to dense molecular packing. In enclosed spaces, shock waves can amplify, increasing injury severity.
  • Solid Blast: Force transmitted through solids, affecting areas in contact with vibrating structures, leading to primary and secondary injuries.

 

Underwater Explosion:

  • Injury to gas-filled organs is more frequent, with the Colon being the most commonly affected organ.
  • Other potential injuries:
    • Perforation of the stomach
    • Small intestine
    • Cecum
    • Lung Injury (Less Common)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male construction worker was involved in a workplace explosion. Positioned near the blast's epicenter, he was swiftly taken to the emergency department with multiple injuries, including punctate abrasions, contusions, and lacerations as depicted in the image. What type of blast injury is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary injury

 

Explanation:

The provided case scenario, along with the accompanying image, illustrates Marshall's triad (contusion, abrasion and punctate laceration), which indicates a secondary blast injury.


Blast Injury: Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, leading to sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

 

 

Classification of Blast Injuries:

Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.

questions.text: In the forensic analysis of cranial fractures, Puppe's Rule is applied to determine the sequence of impacts. According to this rule, when two fracture lines intersect ,as shown below, what can be inferred about their relationship?

choices.text: The line that ends at the intersection is the newer injury.
The second fracture line crosses the first line.
Both fracture lines are of equal age.
Crossing fracture indicates a higher velocity impact.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The Line that ends at the intersection is the newer injury.

 

Explanation:

According to Puppe’s rule, the line that ends at the intersection indicates a more recent injury after forming the initial line.

 

Puppe’s Rule:

It states that the second fracture line does not cross the first when two fracture lines intersect. This principle helps determine the sequence of shots when multiple bullets have impacted the cranium, and it also applies to cases of multiple blunt force impacts on the skull.

 

 

Beveling of Skull:

  • Entry wound: The entry wound presents as a punched-out hole with a clean cut on the outer table and a bevelled appearance on the inner table, where the bone remains unsupported, leading to chipping.
  • Exit wound: The exit wound on the inner table shows a clean-cut hole with beveling on the outer table. It is typically larger than the entry wound due to the bullet's deformation and tumbling upon entering the skull.

 

 

 

 

Kronlein Shot: Rare injury caused by a high-velocity bullet, resulting in bursting of the skull, laceration of the dura, and evisceration of the brain. An autopsy of the skull could not determine the appearance of primary gunshot wounds and entry or exit wounds.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was found dead in an abandoned warehouse due to a shotgun wound to the chest. Analysis indicated that the shotgun pellets caused an effect where multiple pellets, fired from a high range, impacted the same area, leading to significant damage and a larger wound channel. What effect is being described here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Balling effect

 

Explanation:

The effect described above, where multiple pellets fired from a high range impact the same area and create a larger wound channel, is known as the balling effect.

 

Billiard ball effect vs Balling or welding

Billiard ball effect

(Billiard Ball Ricochet Effect) (Option A)

Balling or welding

(Option B)

When shotgun pellets enter tissue, the first pellets slow down and are struck from behind by subsequent pellets, causing them to scatter through the tissue like a cluster of billiard balls hit by the cue ball.

In distant shots, the pellets can merge into a compact mass, causing the lead shots to stick together and create a larger entry wound while exhibiting some dispersion.
It occurs due to:

  • Faulty manufacture (too much powder, poor pressure of wads,paraffin into cartridge case)
  • Old ammunition

Very high dispersion (due to resistance)

Less dispersion

Low range (near shot resembles distant range)

High range (wound mimics intermediate shot)

 

Rayalseena phenomenon (Option C): To disguise a murder as a firearm injury, a bullet is placed in an individual who was initially killed by a stab wound, misleading the investigating agency.

 

Kennedy phenomenon (Option D): Identifying the wound becomes challenging due to surgical alterations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was shot during a robbery while walking home at night. The weapon used was identified as a firearm, and forensic investigators recovered a bullet from the scene, as shown in the image below. Identify it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dum dum bullet

 

Explanation:

The image depicts a Dum Dum bullet, which is a type of semi-jacketed bullet.

 

Types of Bullets

 

Type

Description

Images

Dum-dum bullet

(Option D)

A jacketed bullet that leaves an area near the nose uncovered to expose the core.

Hollow point bullet

(Option A)

The modern Dum Dum bullet features a pit at the nose. Upon impact, pressure in the pit causes the lead ring to expand into a mushroom shape, resulting in increased soft tissue damage and a higher incapacitation index.

Soft point bullet

A jacketed bullet with an open tip that exposes some lead inside expands upon impact but more slowly than a hollow-point bullet.

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet)

Bullets eject one after another when the first bullet fails to exit the barrel and is pushed out by a subsequently fired bullet (faulty ammunition or a firearm that hasn't been used for years).

Duplex bullet

It contains two projectiles by design (used in military rifles) and enters a target at different points.

Frangible bullet

Designed to fragment or disintegrate upon impact, made of copper, powdered tungsten, lead, or iron. They do not ricochet.

Souvenir or sleeping

Bullet (Option B)

A bullet remains in the body for a long time without fresh bleeding, surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. It can result in lead poisoning.

  

Armour-piercing bullet

A jacketed bullet (penetrates armour) with an inner core of hard, high-density metal like tungsten, tungsten carbide, depleted uranium, or steel, featuring a truncated cone.

Incendiary bullet

(Option C)

A type of military bullet designed to ignite a fire in the target.

Tracer bullet

It leaves a visible mark or "trace" during flight, allowing the shooter to see where the shot impacts.

Nontoxic shot or Green bullet

It replaces the copper-jacketed lead core with a copper-jacketed tungsten, steel, bismuth, tin, or nylon core. It does not release toxic lead (lead-free) into the environment (green bullet).

Exploding bullet

A bullet designed to detonate or break apart uses an explosive or deflagrant, causing extensive damage to the victim. These bullets pose a risk to medical personnel, as they may explode during procedures if they fail to detonate in the body.

Boat tail bullet

The cartridge's rear end is tapered rather than squared off to stabilise the projectile in flight.

Poisoned bullets

Contains curare, ricin or aflatoxin.

  

Wadcutter

Specifically designed for shooting paper targets at close range and high velocities.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was participating in a target shooting session at a local outdoor range when he accidentally fired a bullet that deflected off a metal target and struck another participant, resulting in his death. Which of the following best describes the bullet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ricochet bullet

 

Explanation:

The scenario presented, in which a bullet deflects off a surface before striking the target, is characterised as a Ricochet Bullet.

 

Ricochet Bullet:

  • A ricochet bullet is a projectile that rebounds or deflects from its original path after striking an intermediate surface.
  • The critical angle for ricochet is approximately 30 degrees.
  • Wound Characteristics:
    • No Abrasion Collar: Due to the loss of spin and rotation.
    • Absence of Burning, Blackening, and Tattooing
    • Atypical Wound Patterns: Resulting from the bullet's secondary movements after ricocheting.
  • Common Bullet Types Associated with Ricochets
    • Round-nose bullets
    • Full metal jacketed bullets
    • Low-velocity bullets

 

Yawning bullet (Option A) travels irregularly instead of travelling nose-on.

 

 

Tumbling bullet (Option C) rotates end to end during its motion.

 

Tandem bullet (Option D) refers to the simultaneous exit of two bullets (due to previously stuck bullet), also known as a piggyback bullet.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was found dead after a suspected shooting incident involving a shotgun. During the investigation, experts examined the shotgun's characteristics to determine factors affecting its range. Which of the following does not enhance the range of shotguns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Elongated and pointed bullet

 

Explanation:

An elongated and pointed bullet does not enhance the effective range of shotguns.

 

Factors Enhancing the Range of Firearms

  1. Shotgun

Paradox gun: A mixed gun incorporating characteristics of both a rifle and a shotgun, featuring a shotgun design with a rifled section in the barrel towards the muzzle end.

  • Choking: Constriction at the muzzle end of a shotgun in order to:
    • Reduce the dispersion of lead shot
    • Enhance the velocity of the pellets

 

  • Types of choking:

Type

Range

Cylindrical base (unchoked)

25 yards

Improved cylindrical choke

30 yads

Modified cylindrical choke

35 yards

Full choke

40 yards

 

 

 

  1. Rifled Firearm
  • Elongated and pointed bullet (Option A): Aerodynamic shape reduces air resistance, allowing the bullet to maintain velocity and travel farther.
  • Lands and Grooves (Rifling) (Option B): Imparts spin to the bullet, stabilising it in flight and improving accuracy and range.
  • Calibre (Distance between two opposite lands) (Option C): Larger calibers maintain stability and energy over longer distances, contributing to extended range.

 

 

 

  • Barrel length: A longer barrel increases bullet velocity by allowing more time for propellant gases to act, enhancing range.
  • Ammunition Type: High-performance bullets reduce drag, improving aerodynamic efficiency and range.
  • Muzzle Velocity: Higher initial bullet speed reduces the effects of gravity and air resistance, extending range.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was shot outside a nightclub late at night. Witnesses reported hearing gunshots and saw a dark sedan fleeing the scene. Police found shell casings and a bloodstained area, collecting gunshot residue (GSR) samples from the victim's hands and clothing. Which of the following is the most specific gunshot residue test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) SEM-EDXA’

 

Explanation:

The most specific Gunshot Residue (GSR) Test is SEM-EDXA (Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis).


 

Gunshot Residue (GSR) Tests:

Test

Description

Harrison and Gilroy test (Option A)

A qualitative calorimetric chemical test detects antimony, barium, and lead but is not specific to firearm discharge residues.

Atomic absorption Spectrometry (AAS) &

Flameless atomic absorption spectrophotometry (FAAS)

(Option B)
  • Uses high temperatures to vaporise metallic elements in primer residues for detection and quantification.
  • Measuring antimony, barium, and lead from the primer, along with copper from the cartridge case or bullet jacketing.

Neutron activation analysis

(Option C)
  • Identifies minute traces of elements in hair, nails, soil, glass, paint, gunshot residue (GSR), and drugs by detecting radioisotopes formed through irradiation in a nuclear reactor.
  • Antimony and copper residues from the primer can be found on the suspect's hand.

SEM-EDXA (Scanning electron microscopy energy dispersive X-ray analysis) (Option D)
  • It is the most advanced tool for detecting minute traces of gunshot residue (GSR) on a suspect's body, providing qualitative rather than quantitative analysis.
  • It is the most specific test.

Dermal Nitrate Test (Paraffin Test)

An obsolete and non-specific method for detecting gunshot residue (GSR) by identifying nitrates and nitrites on a suspect's hand

questions.text: A forensic investigator is analysing the injuries caused by a bullet at a crime scene. Which of the following best describes the study of the interaction between a projectile and its target?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Terminal Ballistics

 

Explanation:

Terminal Ballistics refers to the study of how a projectile behaves when it strikes and interacts with its target, including the damage inflicted upon tissues or materials.

 

Classification of Ballistics:

  • Internal Ballistics (Proximal Ballistics): Study of the firearm and the projectile's behaviour from the moment the trigger is pulled until it exits the barrel.
  • External Ballistics (Intermediate Ballistics): Analysis of a projectile's motion after it leaves the barrel and until it reaches the target.
  • Terminal Ballistics: Study of the interaction between a projectile and its target upon impact.
  • Wound Ballistics: Study of motion and effects of projectile in the tissue.

questions.text: In a forensic investigation of a 45-year-old male found dead from a gunshot wound, the scene indicates forced entry, with the front door ajar and a bullet and shell casing collected. Which of the following are not considered primary markings on the bullet?

choices.text: Diameter and width of lands and grooves

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Surface irregularities from barrel imperfections

 

Explanation:

  • Primary markings on bullets include the number, diameter, and width of lands and grooves (striations) and the degree of rifling twist.
  • Surface irregularities serve as secondary markings.
  • These markings allow forensic experts to connect bullets from a crime scene to a specific firearm, aiding in criminal investigations.

 

Primary Markings (Class characteristics)

Secondary Markings (Individual or accidental characteristics)

  • It consists of:

    • Depth of grooves
    • Direction and degree of rifling twist (Option C)

Surface irregularities (Option D) on the bullet result from imperfections in the barrel and the adhesion of bullet particles to the bore during firing (Metallic Fouling).

It may be identical for bullets fired by two different weapons.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is found deceased in his apartment with a gunshot wound, and police find a firearm at the scene, along with traces of smokeless gunpowder on the victim's hands. What is the composition of single-base smokeless gunpowder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Nitrocellulose

 

Explanation:

  • Nitrocellulose or Gun cotton is the main component of single-base smokeless gunpowder.
  • They produce less heat, smoke, and flame than traditional black gunpowder.
  • They produce around 12000 to 13000 cc of gas.
  • Smokeless gunpowder is of 3 types:
    • Single base: Nitrocellulose
    • Double base: Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine (Option B)
    • Triple base: Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine + Nitroguanidine (Option C)
  • They come in various G like flakes, discs, globules, squares, rectangles and cylinders.




Potassium nitrate (Option C), combined with sulfur and charcoal, forms the composition of Black Gunpowder.

questions.solution:

  • Gunpowder is graded by the letter F, like F, FF, and FFF, where the number of Fs is directly proportional to the powder's fineness and burning speed.

These days, this is mainly replaced by smokeless powder and is only used in a few areas, such as fireworks, mining, and military use.

Wads are used in all types of cartridges
Rifle bullets are generally elongated with a pointed tip
Rifle bullets and shotgun pellets are made of lead

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wads are used in all types of cartridges

 

Explanation:

  • Wads are specifically used only in smooth-bore shotgun cartridges, not rifle cartridges.

 

Cartridge:

  • A cartridge is a complete unit of ammunition consisting of the following components:
    • Cartridge case: Contains the percussion cap with primer.
    • Propellant charge: Typically gunpowder.
    • Projectile: This can be bullets or pellets.

 

Cartridge of Rifle

Cartridge of Shotgun
  • Contains a primer on the base and a cartridge case filled with gunpowder.
  • Features a single projectile (bullet).
  • Does not include a wad (Option B)
  • Contains lead shots (Option D)/Pellets (Multiple Projectiles) (Option A)
  • Wads: Used only in smoothbore weapons (Shotguns).
  • Advantages of Wads:
    • Facilitates optimal pressure.
    • Prevents gas escape from the bore.
    • Aids in lubrication.
    • Stops gas from escaping at the breech end.
    • Maintains separation between the propellant and projectiles.

 

 

Bullet:

  • A projectile that exits the muzzle of a rifled firearm upon discharge.
  • Material: Typically made from soft metal, primarily lead (Option D), often with added antimony and/or tin for increased hardness.
  • Shape:
    • Round nose soft bullet: Commonly used in revolvers and pistols.
    • Rifle bullets: Generally elongated with a pointed tip. (Option C)
  • Types:
    • Lead bullets: Made entirely of lead, offering expansion upon impact.
    • Metal-Jacketed Bullets: A lead core encased in a metal jacket (usually copper) enhances accuracy and reduces barrel fouling.
      • They also prevent deformation from dirt and impacts and reduce fragmentation to protect the firearm from damage.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation, experts discussed the benefits of rifled firearms and how rifling impacts evidence collection. All the following are advantages of rifling except?

choices.text: Increases accuracy by stabilizing the bullet
Improves range by imparting spin to the projectile
Reduces wobbling of the bullet in flight

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Limits spread of pellets

 

Explanation:

Limiting the spread of pellets is a characteristic more associated with smooth-bore shotguns (not rifled firearms), achieved through a process known as Choking.

 

Choking

Rifling ( Rifled Firearms)
  • Definition: Choking refers to the constriction at the muzzle end of a shotgun barrel.
  • Types:
    • Cylinder Bore: The barrel has a uniform diameter throughout.
    • Choke Bore: The muzzle is slightly constricted.
  • Degrees of Choke: Full, modified, improved cylinder, and cylinder.
  • Advantages of Choking:
    • Reduces shot spread.
    • Increases explosive force.
    • Enhances velocity and range.
  • Dispersion: A fully choked barrel produces shot dispersion that is half that of a cylinder bore.
  • As the bullet travels through the bore, it engages with the rifling, imparting a spin that enhances accuracy and stability. Each weapon leaves a unique marking on the bullet, aiding forensic identification.
  • Advantages of Rifling:
    • Gyroscopic Stability
    • Increased Accuracy (Option A):
    • Increased Range (stability and spin) (Option B)
    • Reduced Wobbling (Option D) (tumbling end-over-end during flight)
    • Greater Penetration Power

questions.text: During a forensic analysis of a crime scene, investigators examined firearms and noted the distinctions between rifled and smooth-bore firearms. Which of the following is true regarding rifled and smooth-bore firearms

choices.text: Rifled firearms usually have multiple projectiles
Smooth-bore firearms include handguns and revolvers
Shotguns typically have a smooth barrel
Smooth-bore firearms typically don’t have chokes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Shotguns typically have a smooth barrel

 

Explanation:

Shotguns belong to the smooth-bore firearms, which usually have uniformly smooth barrels.

 

Difference between Rifled & Smooth Bore Firearms:

Feature

Rifled Firearms

Smooth Bore Firearms

Barrel Interior

Contains spiral grooves (Rifling)

Uniformly smooth barrel without grooves

Measurement

Caliber: Diameter between opposite lands, measured before rifling grooves are cut.

Bore: Defined by the number of lead balls of a specific size (diameter) that can be made from one pound of lead (454 grams).

Bullet Type

Typically fires a single projectile (bullet) (Option A)

Fires multiple pellets (shot) or a single slug

Accuracy

Higher due to rifling

Lower accuracy, designed for spread over a wide area.

Functionality

Imparts spin to the bullet for greater stability and precision

Fires multiple projectiles simultaneously for short-range effectiveness

Choke

Usually not applicable

May have chokes to control the spread of the shot (Option D)

Examples

Rifles, Pistols, Revolvers (Option B)

Shotguns

questions.text: At a forensic lab, a team was examining evidence from a recent shooting. One forensic analyst pointed out that identifying the caliber of the gun can help in linking it to a specific weapon. What does the term "caliber" refer to in forensic ballistics?

choices.text: Muzzle design influencing the dispersion of shot
Measurement of the diameter of the shotgun barrel

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Distance between two opposite lands

 

Explanation:

In forensic ballistics, "caliber" refers to the diameter of a rifled firearm's barrel, specifically measured between opposing lands. This measurement, typically expressed in inches or millimetres, is crucial for linking a bullet to a specific firearm.

 

Rifled Firearms:

  • Rifled firearms have a bore characterised by a series of grooves that spiral along the barrel's length. These grooves (Option B), known as "rifling," alternate with raised areas called "lands." The caliber is determined by measuring the distance between these lands.
  • The direction of rifling can be either right (clockwise) or left (counter-clockwise), with most handguns featuring a right-hand twist.

As the bullet travels through the barrel, it engages with the lands and grooves, imparting a spin that stabilises its flight and leaves distinctive markings on the bullet, which serve as identifiers for the firearm.

 

 

Muzzle constriction controlling shot spread (Option C): This refers to the Choke, which narrows the barrel's end to control the dispersion of shot pellets as they exit, influencing the effectiveness of the shotgun at different ranges.


Measurement of shotgun bore diameter (Option D): This describes the Gauge, indicating the size of the shotgun bore, which is determined by the number of lead balls corresponding to the diameter of shotgun bore that can be made from one pound of lead.
